claim: In Ireland, almost everyone speaks English.

supporting.text: English is the primary official language of Ireland, spoken by the vast majority of the population.

attacks.text: English is the primary official language of Ireland, spoken by the vast majority of the population.
A significant portion of the Irish population speaks Irish (Gaeilge) as their first language, particularly in Gaeltacht regions.
While Irish is spoken in Gaeltacht regions, these areas constitute a small percentage of Ireland's total population, and English remains dominant nationwide.
English is not the first language for many immigrants and non-native residents in Ireland, who may speak other languages at home.
Even among immigrants, English is widely learned and used for daily communication, making it effectively universal in Ireland.

supporting.text: According to the 2016 Irish Census, over 98% of the population reported being able to speak English.

attacks.text: According to the 2016 Irish Census, over 98% of the population reported being able to speak English.
The census data relies on self-reporting, which may overestimate actual English proficiency due to social desirability bias.
Studies show self-reported language proficiency correlates highly with objective measures, especially in countries with widespread education in the language.
The 2% who don't speak English may be concentrated in certain regions, making English not universally spoken in all parts of Ireland.
Even in Gaeltacht (Irish-speaking) regions, over 90% of residents are bilingual in English according to the same census.

supporting.text: Irish (Gaeilge) is the national and first official language, but English is the dominant language in daily use.

attacks.text: Irish (Gaeilge) is the national and first official language, but English is the dominant language in daily use.
In certain Gaeltacht regions, Irish is the primary language spoken at home and in daily life, not English.
Gaeltacht regions are a small minority of Ireland's population, and English remains dominant even there for many practical purposes.
Official government documents and road signs are bilingual, showing Irish has significant institutional presence beyond just being a 'national' language.
Bilingual signage and documents are symbolic; most Irish people interact with these materials primarily in English due to widespread fluency.

supporting.text: Public education, government, and media in Ireland predominantly operate in English.

attacks.text: Public education, government, and media in Ireland predominantly operate in English.
Irish (Gaeilge) is the first official language of Ireland, and some regions (Gaeltacht) primarily speak Irish.
Even in Gaeltacht regions, English is widely understood and used in daily life alongside Irish.
Not all public services and media are exclusively in English; some are bilingual or Irish-language only.
Bilingual services are a minority, and most mainstream media and government functions default to English.

supporting.text: While Irish is taught in schools, fluency in Irish is not as widespread as fluency in English.

attacks.text: While Irish is taught in schools, fluency in Irish is not as widespread as fluency in English.
Some regions in Ireland, like Gaeltacht areas, have a significant population that speaks Irish as their first language.
Even in Gaeltacht areas, English is commonly used in daily life, reducing the practical dominance of Irish.
Irish language revival efforts have increased fluency among younger generations, challenging the notion that English is universally dominant.
Despite revival efforts, English remains the primary language of media, business, and government, limiting Irish's practical reach.
